title: Dystonia
scope: ** Diagnosis, classification, workup for secondary causes, and symptomatic management of dystonia. Covers focal (cervical, blepharospasm, writer's cramp), segmental, and generalized forms. Includes evaluation for Wilson's disease, dopa-responsive dystonia, and drug-induced dystonia.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Electrolyte abnormalities can exacerbate movement disorders

Essential/Core Labs.item: Hepatic panel (AST, ALT, Alk Phos, bilirubin, albumin)
Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Screen for hepatic dysfunction suggesting Wilson's disease
Wilson's disease screen; essential for age <50 with dystonia

Extended Workup.rationale: Wilson's disease confirmation if ceruloplasmin low/borderline
Interpret with ceruloplasmin (low free copper ratio in Wilson's)
Deficiency causes myelopathy and movement disorders
Hypocalcemia, hypomagnesemia can cause movement disorders
Elevated in dystonia crises, NMS, prolonged dystonic posturing

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Atypical presentations; family history; early onset

Essential/First-line.item: MRI Brain without and with contrast
Essential/First-line.timing: All new dystonia cases; rule out structural lesion

Extended.target: No T2 hypointensity in basal ganglia

Extended.timing: Confirm diagnosis; characterize pattern; guide botulinum toxin
Differentiate dystonic tremor from PD; combined dystonia-parkinsonism
Extended.target: Normal in primary dystonia; abnormal if parkinsonism

dosing.instructions: 25-50 mg IV/IM over 2-5 min; may repeat in 30 min if needed; max 100 mg
1-2 mg IV/IM; may repeat in 30 min; follow with oral 1-2 mg BID x 2-3 days to prevent recurrence

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Narrow-angle glaucoma; GI obstruction; myasthenia gravis

dosing.instructions: 1-2 mg IV slow push or 2-4 mg PO; may repeat q4-6h PRN; monitor respiratory status

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Severe respiratory depression; acute narrow-angle glaucoma

dosing.instructions: 5-10 mg IV slow push (2 mg/min) or PO; may repeat q4h PRN

doseOptions.orderSentence: OnabotulinumtoxinA (Botox) - Cervical dystonia 100 units total IM
OnabotulinumtoxinA (Botox) - Cervical dystonia 200 units total IM
OnabotulinumtoxinA (Botox) - Cervical dystonia 300 units total IM

dosing.instructions: Start 100-200 units divided among affected muscles (SCM, splenius, trapezius, levator scapulae); adjust based on response; max 300 units/session; repeat q12wk
dosing.orderSentence: OnabotulinumtoxinA (Botox) - Cervical dystonia 100 units total IM

Symptomatic Treatments (First-line for F.contraindications: Infection at site; myasthenia gravis; ALS
Symptomatic Treatments (First-line for F.monitoring: Dysphagia (especially bilateral SCM); neck weakness; antibody formation

dosing.instructions: 1.25-5 units per site; inject orbicularis oculi at multiple points; total 25-50 units per eye; repeat q12wk

Symptomatic Treatments (First-line for F.indication: Focal hand dystonia refractory to therapy modification

doseOptions.orderSentence: OnabotulinumtoxinA (Botox) - Writer's cramp 50 units total IM
OnabotulinumtoxinA (Botox) - Writer's cramp 100 units total IM

dosing.instructions: 10-50 units per muscle; EMG guidance required; target FCR, FCU, FDS as needed; repeat q12wk
dosing.orderSentence: OnabotulinumtoxinA (Botox) - Writer's cramp 50 units total IM

doseOptions.orderSentence: AbobotulinumtoxinA (Dysport) - Cervical dystonia 500 units total IM
AbobotulinumtoxinA (Dysport) - Cervical dystonia 750 units total IM
AbobotulinumtoxinA (Dysport) - Cervical dystonia 1000 units total IM

dosing.instructions: Start 500 units divided among affected muscles; max 1000 units/session; repeat q12wk
dosing.orderSentence: AbobotulinumtoxinA (Dysport) - Cervical dystonia 500 units total IM

doseOptions.orderSentence: IncobotulinumtoxinA (Xeomin) - Cervical dystonia 120 units total IM
IncobotulinumtoxinA (Xeomin) - Cervical dystonia 200 units total IM
IncobotulinumtoxinA (Xeomin) - Cervical dystonia 300 units total IM

dosing.instructions: Start 120-200 units divided; max 300 units/session; repeat q12wk; may have lower immunogenicity
dosing.orderSentence: IncobotulinumtoxinA (Xeomin) - Cervical dystonia 120 units total IM

Symptomatic Treatments (First-line for F.indication: Type A toxin non-responders; secondary non-response

RimabotulinumtoxinB (Myobloc) - Cervical dystonia 5000 units total IM
RimabotulinumtoxinB (Myobloc) - Cervical dystonia 10000 units total IM

dosing.instructions: Start 2500-5000 units divided; max 10000 units; repeat q12wk; higher dry mouth rate
dosing.orderSentence: RimabotulinumtoxinB (Myobloc) - Cervical dystonia 2500 units total IM

Second-line/Oral Medications.indication: First-line oral for generalized dystonia; young patients tolerate best

dosing.instructions: Start 1 mg daily; increase by 1-2 mg q3-5d; typical target 6-30 mg/day divided TID; some patients require up to 60-80 mg/day

Second-line/Oral Medications.contraindications: Narrow-angle glaucoma; GI obstruction; urinary retention; dementia
Second-line/Oral Medications.monitoring: Anticholinergic effects (dry mouth, constipation, urinary retention, confusion); cognitive effects in elderly

Second-line/Oral Medications.indication: Alternative anticholinergic; maintenance after acute dystonic reaction

dosing.instructions: Start 0.5 mg BID; increase by 0.5 mg q5-7d; typical 1-4 mg/day; max 6 mg/day

Second-line/Oral Medications.indication: Muscle relaxant; useful adjunct for dystonia

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg TID; increase by 5 mg/dose q3d; typical 30-80 mg/day divided TID; max 80-120 mg/day

Second-line/Oral Medications.contraindications: Severe renal impairment (dose adjust); abrupt withdrawal risk
Second-line/Oral Medications.monitoring: Sedation, weakness; taper slowly if discontinuing

dosing.instructions: Start 0.25 mg BID; increase by 0.25-0.5 mg q3-7d; typical 1-4 mg/day; max 6 mg/day

Second-line/Oral Medications.contraindications: Respiratory depression; severe hepatic impairment; substance abuse history
Second-line/Oral Medications.monitoring: Sedation, dependence, falls; taper if discontinuing

dosing.instructions: Start 2 mg TID; increase by 2-5 mg/day q3-7d; typical 10-40 mg/day divided

Second-line/Oral Medications.indication: Dopa-responsive dystonia (DRD); diagnostic trial for young-onset

dosing.instructions: Start 25/100 mg TID; if DRD, dramatic response at low dose; may titrate to 50/200 mg TID; response confirms diagnosis

Second-line/Oral Medications.contraindications: None absolute; use caution in psychosis
Second-line/Oral Medications.monitoring: Nausea, orthostatic hypotension; dramatic improvement suggests DRD

dosing.instructions: Start 12.5 mg daily; increase by 12.5 mg q1wk; max 200 mg/day; CYP2D6 testing recommended

Second-line/Oral Medications.monitoring: Depression, sedation, parkinsonism, akathisia; Black Box: suicidality

dosing.instructions: Start 6 mg BID; increase by 6 mg/day weekly; max 48 mg/day

Second-line/Oral Medications.monitoring: Same but may be better tolerated

Second-line/Oral Medications.indication: Adjunct; may help in some patients

dosing.instructions: Start 0.1 mg BID; increase by 0.1 mg q1wk; max 0.6 mg/day

Second-line/Oral Medications.monitoring: Hypotension, bradycardia, sedation; rebound hypertension if stopped abruptly

dosing.instructions: Start 100 mg BID; increase by 100-200 mg q1wk; target 400-800 mg/day; check HLA-B*1502 in at-risk populations

Second-line/Oral Medications.contraindications: Bone marrow suppression; AV block; SJS risk (HLA-B*1502)
Second-line/Oral Medications.monitoring: CBC, LFTs, sodium; drug levels (4-12 mcg/mL)

Disease-Modifying/Specialized Therapies.indication: Medication-refractory generalized or segmental dystonia; DYT1 positive

doseOptions.orderSentence: Deep brain stimulation (GPi-DBS) Bilateral GPi stimulation Surgical

dosing.instructions: Bilateral GPi electrode placement; programming over weeks-months; full effect may take 6-12 months
dosing.orderSentence: Deep brain stimulation (GPi-DBS) Bilateral GPi stimulation Surgical

Disease-Modifying/Specialized Therapies.pretreatment: MRI; neuropsych testing; multidisciplinary evaluation; genetic testing if indicated
Disease-Modifying/Specialized Therapies.contraindications: Cognitive impairment; coagulopathy; infection; unrealistic expectations
Disease-Modifying/Specialized Therapies.monitoring: Programming optimization; battery replacement q3-5yr; speech/swallowing

Disease-Modifying/Specialized Therapies.indication: Cervical dystonia refractory to botulinum toxin

doseOptions.orderSentence: Deep brain stimulation (GPi-DBS) Bilateral GPi stimulation Surgical

dosing.instructions: Same as above
dosing.orderSentence: Deep brain stimulation (GPi-DBS) Bilateral GPi stimulation Surgical

Disease-Modifying/Specialized Therapies.indication: Severe generalized dystonia with spasticity component; CP-related

doseOptions.orderSentence: Intrathecal baclofen pump Continuous IT infusion IT

dosing.instructions: Test dose 25-100 mcg; maintenance typically 100-1000 mcg/day; titrate over months
dosing.orderSentence: Intrathecal baclofen pump Continuous IT infusion IT

Disease-Modifying/Specialized Therapies.monitoring: Pump refills q1-3mo; withdrawal syndrome if interruption; MRI conditional pumps

dosing.instructions: Start 250 mg daily; increase by 250 mg q4-7d; target 1000-1500 mg/day divided BID (take 1hr before meals); lifelong treatment

Disease-Modifying/Specialized Therapies.contraindications: Penicillin allergy (not absolute but caution); nephrotoxicity
Disease-Modifying/Specialized Therapies.monitoring: CBC weekly x1mo then monthly x6mo then q3mo; urinalysis monthly; LFTs monthly; neurologic worsening first 6 months possible

dosing.instructions: Start 250 mg TID; target 750-1250 mg/day divided TID; take 1hr before or 2hr after meals

Disease-Modifying/Specialized Therapies.monitoring: Same monitoring as D-penicillamine; fewer side effects

dosing.instructions: 50 mg TID (elemental zinc); take between meals; blocks intestinal copper absorption

Disease-Modifying/Specialized Therapies.monitoring: 24h urine copper; serum zinc; 24h urine zinc

Referrals & Consults.item: Movement disorders neurology for diagnosis confirmation, classification, and treatment planning
Ophthalmology for slit lamp examination to evaluate for Kayser-Fleischer rings (Wilson's disease workup)
Hepatology if Wilson's disease diagnosed for hepatic management and transplant evaluation if severe
Genetic counseling if genetic dystonia confirmed or suspected (DYT1, DYT6, GCH1)
Neurosurgery consultation for DBS evaluation if medication-refractory
Physical therapy for posture correction, stretching, and range of motion exercises
Occupational therapy for adaptive techniques and assistive devices for ADLs
Speech therapy if oromandibular dystonia, laryngeal dystonia, or cervical dystonia affecting swallowing
Pain management if chronic pain from dystonic posturing not controlled with primary treatment
Psychology/psychiatry for coping strategies, depression/anxiety management related to chronic dystonia

Patient Instructions.item: After botulinum toxin injection: avoid rubbing injection sites; effects develop over 3-14 days and last 10-12 weeks
Report any swallowing difficulty or breathing problems after botulinum toxin injection (may indicate spread)
Use sensory tricks (geste antagoniste) such as touching chin or face which may temporarily reduce cervical dystonia
Return to ED if severe muscle spasms with fever, confusion, or dark urine (possible dystonic storm or rhabdomyolysis)
Continue physical therapy exercises at home to maintain range of motion and prevent contractures
Avoid medications that worsen dystonia: metoclopramide, prochlorperazine, haloperidol, and other dopamine blockers
For Wilson's disease: strict adherence to copper chelation is lifelong; follow dietary copper restrictions
Keep a symptom diary noting triggers, sensory tricks that help, and response to medications

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Stress management with relaxation techniques as stress can exacerbate dystonia
Adequate sleep as fatigue worsens dystonia symptoms
Limit caffeine and stimulants which may worsen tremor/dystonia
Regular gentle exercise (swimming, yoga) to maintain flexibility without overexertion
Ergonomic workstation modifications for task-specific dystonia (writer's cramp, musician's dystonia)
For Wilson's disease: avoid high-copper foods (liver, shellfish, chocolate, nuts, mushrooms) especially during initial treatment
Avoid alcohol especially if on benzodiazepines or with hepatic involvement (Wilson's)
Heat application to affected muscles may provide temporary relief
Support groups for dystonia provide coping strategies and community connection

differential.features: Temporal relationship with dopamine blockers (antipsychotics, antiemetics); acute or tardive
differential.tests: Medication history; resolves with withdrawal (acute) or persists (tardive)

differential.features: Age <50; hepatic dysfunction; psychiatric symptoms; Kayser-Fleischer rings
differential.tests: Ceruloplasmin (low), 24h urine copper (high), slit lamp exam, ATP7B testing

differential.features: Childhood onset; diurnal fluctuation (worse evening); dramatic levodopa response
differential.tests: Levodopa trial (dramatic improvement); GCH1 gene testing

differential.features: Rest tremor; bradykinesia; rigidity; asymmetric; sustained postures
Inconsistent; distractible; fixed posture from onset; associated somatization
differential.tests: Clinical features; psychiatric evaluation; resolution with distraction

differential.features: Axial rigidity; episodic spasms triggered by startle; anti-GAD antibodies
differential.tests: Anti-GAD65 antibodies; EMG (continuous motor unit activity)

differential.features: Prolonged dopamine blocker exposure (months-years); may persist after withdrawal
differential.tests: History of antipsychotic/antiemetic use; AIMS assessment

differential.features: Neck pain; sensory symptoms; hyperreflexia; Hoffmann sign
Constant head tilt; headache; papilledema; cranial nerve signs
Chorea; orofacial dystonia; lip/tongue biting; elevated CK
differential.tests: Acanthocyte smear; CK; VPS13A gene testing

differential.features: Progressive; childhood/young adult onset; parkinsonism; retinopathy

differential.tests: Clinical diagnosis; rule out secondary causes

differential.features: Myoclonic jerks + dystonia; alcohol responsive; SGCE gene
Brief attacks (<1 min); triggered by sudden movement; responds to carbamazepine

evidence.recommendation: Botulinum toxin first-line for cervical dystonia
DBS superior effect in DYT1-positive patients
Levodopa trial for suspected dopa-responsive dystonia

evidence.source: [van Harten PN et al. J Clin Psychiatry 1999](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/10401919/)

evidence.recommendation: EFNS guidelines on dystonia diagnosis and treatment
evidence.source: [Albanese A et al. Eur J Neurol 2011](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20649898/)

monitoring.item: Dystonia severity (Burke-Fahn-Marsden scale, TWSTRS for cervical)
monitoring.action: Adjust botulinum toxin dose/muscles; add oral agent; consider DBS
OT/PT referral; adaptive devices; treatment escalation

monitoring.item: Anticholinergic side effects (dry mouth, constipation, urinary retention, cognition)
monitoring.action: Reduce dose; switch agents; add symptomatic treatment
Dietary modification; speech therapy; reduce dose next session

monitoring.item: CK level (if severe dystonia or dystonic storm)
monitoring.action: IV fluids; monitor renal function; treat underlying cause
Hold drug if cytopenias or proteinuria; switch to trientine
Reprogram; schedule battery replacement if needed

disposition.criteria: New diagnosis with workup initiated; mild symptoms; treatment plan in place; follow-up scheduled
Acute dystonic reaction requiring observation; new generalized dystonia requiring workup; Wilson's disease with hepatic decompensation
Status dystonicus (dystonic storm); respiratory compromise; rhabdomyolysis; severe drug-induced dystonia with airway concern
DBS programming issues requiring movement disorders center; refractory status dystonicus requiring specialized center
2-4 weeks after new medication started; 12 weeks for botulinum toxin reassessment; 6-12 months when stable
